document.masterDocTitle: A review of the genus Ancylosis Zeller, 1839 (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae: Phycitinae) from Ukraine

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the genus Ancylosis Zeller, 1839 (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae: Phycitinae) from Ukraine

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ephestia oblitella Zeller, 1848
—Isis: 597. TL: Volgograd [Sarepta], Russia .
Aucmera homographis Hampson, 1930 —Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. (10) 5: 65. TL: Batna , Algeria .

Trissonca ischnopis Meyrick, 1937
—Exot. Microlep. 5: 70. TL: Mosul, Iraq .

Heterographis oblitella var. major Lucas, 1948
—Bull. Soc. ent. France 53: 89. TL: Sfax , Tunisia .

Heterographis oblitella var. ochraeella Lucas, 1948
—Bull. Soc. ent. France 53: 89. TL: Sfax , Tunisia .

Heterographis boitelella Lucas, 1950
—Bull. Soc. ent. France 53: 142. TL: Sidi-bel-Abbés , Algeria .

Heterographis calaritanella Amsel, 1951
—Fragm. Ent. 1: 101, fig. 2. TL: Cagliari, Sardinia .

Heterographis indistinctella Lucas, 1955
—Bull. Soc. sci. nat. Maroc . 35: 253. TL: Casablanca, Morocco .

Diagnosis.
Ancylosis oblitella
is a dark greyish-black species with white serrated transverse ante-medial and post-medial lines, black patch mixed with ochreous-brown on ⅓ near the dorsal margin and with ochreous-brown elongated spot in fold. For the differences from
A. cinnamomella
and
A. roscidella
see under those species. The gradually bend and broad valva, nearly as broad as long saccus, the long juxta (twice as long as broad) and comparatively broad and short aedeagus are characteristic for the male genitalia.
Ancylosis substratellum
is somewhat similar but the uncus and valva are broader. The broad ductus bursae with indistinct transition to small, rounded corpus bursae densely covered with snowflakes-shaped, arrow-shaped and thorn-shaped signa are the most characteristic features of the female genitalia. Somewhat similar signa are observed in
A. ustella ( Ragonot, 1887 )
, but they are gathered in one small or two rounded plates in this species.

Biology. The larvae were described by Ford (1957: 27) . They were observed living in spun gallery in loose silken tubes covered with sand beneath the plant of
Suaeda maritima
(L.) Dum ( Roesler 1973: 441 , cit. after Glaser 1960: 157 ). The records of larvae feeding on
Acacia tortilis (Hayne)
and
A. farnesiana (Willd.)
( Roesler 1973: 441 , cit. after, Chrétien 1917: 42 ) need confirmation. Leraut (2014: 408) mentioned also
Chenopodium
as an additional host plant of this species. In Ukraine adults fly from late April to eraly June and then in August-September in two generations.
